df["Yes but Not because of the coronavirus pandemic"]=df["Yes but Not because of the coronavirus pandemic"].apply(int)

#Code by  Orfanakis Konstantinos https://www.kaggle.com/korfanakis/predicting-customer-churn-using-machine-learning

label_size = 17

plt.rcParams['axes.labelsize'] = label_size
plt.rcParams['xtick.labelsize'] = label_size - 2
plt.rcParams['ytick.labelsize'] = label_size - 2
plt.rcParams['axes.titlesize'] = label_size

source.12a254ae:
#Code by  Orfanakis Konstantinos https://www.kaggle.com/korfanakis/predicting-customer-churn-using-machine-learning

colors = ['#00A5E0', '#DD403A']

fig = plt.figure(figsize = (5, 5))
sns.countplot(x = 'Select characteristics', data = df, palette = colors)

for index, value in enumerate(df['Select characteristics'].value_counts()):
    label =  '{}%'.format(round( (value/df['Select characteristics'].shape[0])*100, 2)) 
    plt.annotate(label, xy = (index - 0.18, value - 800), color = 'w', fontweight = 'bold', size = label_size)

plt.title('Teleworking & Presence of children under 18 years old')
plt.xticks([0, 1], ['No children', 'Children in household'])
plt.xlabel('Presence of children under 18 years old')
plt.ylabel('Count');

source.5d8268e0:
df_kids = df[df['Select characteristics'] == 1]
df_noKids = df[df['Select characteristics'] == 0]
source.c07af0b6:
#Code by  Orfanakis Konstantinos https://www.kaggle.com/korfanakis/predicting-customer-churn-using-machine-learning

def plot_continuous(feature):
    
    fig, (ax1, ax2) = plt.subplots(1, 2, figsize = (12, 4))
    
    sns.distplot(df_noKids[feature], bins = 15, color = colors[0], label = 'No Kids', hist_kws = dict(edgecolor = 'firebrick', linewidth = 1), ax = ax1, kde = False)
    sns.distplot(df_kids[feature], bins = 15, color = colors[1], label = 'Kids', hist_kws = dict(edgecolor = 'firebrick', linewidth = 1), ax = ax1, kde = False)
    ax1.set_title('{} distribution - Histogram'.format(feature))
    ax1.set_ylabel('Counts')
    ax1.legend()

    sns.boxplot(x = 'Select characteristics', y = feature, data = df, palette = colors, ax = ax2)
    ax2.set_title('{} distribution - Box plot'.format(feature))
    ax2.set_xlabel('Status')
    ax2.set_xticklabels(['No Kids', 'Kids'])

    plt.tight_layout();
source.516a8347: plot_continuous('Yes Because of the coronavirus pandemic')

source.f1155826:
#Teleworking effectively with children

Define your workspace at home, Enjoy the mornings

Keep them entertained

Set up a daily routine, Set goals for your children, Shop for a few days and cook in advance

Enjoy the naps (That's Great!)

Choose the best time for your remote meetings

Divide and conquer, Find a balance between your private life and your professional life

https://www.resourcesolutions.com/latest-news/10-tips-to-telework-effectively-with-children.html
source.3c6ffc66: #That's the kind of chart I would like to plot when I learn to work properly.
source.6606e2ca:
#The mental health risks of remote work

"Many employees in the coming weeks may experience unanticipated mental health consequences from mandated remote work, and it is important to be cognizant of this reality. Two causes for concern are isolation and burnout. Remote work is a common trend in many industries today, especially tech and business services; many are already familiar with how the solitude of working remotely can impact mental health. For those who are accustomed to and appreciative of conventional “office life” and a steady rate of social interactions at the office, the shift to remote work as a result of social distancing procedure during the Covid-19 pandemic might cause a surprising, even if relatively mild, deterioration of mental health."

https://www.forbes.com/sites/onemind/2020/03/17/when-home-becomes-the-workplace-mental-health-and-remote-work/?sh=6161335d1760
source.c9f814a0:
#Isolation

"Our daily interactions are shown to reinforce our sense of well-being and belonging in a community; and with cities like Los Angeles on lockdown, millions are being forced to not only work from home, but stay at home, as bars, restaurants, and events are closed through March 31. Even in “normal” times, the impact of loneliness and isolation should not be understated; research has shown that it can be “twice as harmful to physical and mental health as obesity.” One study found that for those who normally work remotely, 19% report loneliness. Loneliness is most risky when it is chronic, which, for many who live alone, could become a temporary reality as more and more people are encouraged to stay home during the coronavirus pandemic."

https://www.forbes.com/sites/onemind/2020/03/17/when-home-becomes-the-workplace-mental-health-and-remote-work/?sh=6161335d1760
